thoughts.text: It seems that the execute_shell command is not working for LISP code. One possible solution is to use the execute_python_file command to run LISP code. Another solution is to save the LISP code to a .lisp file and use the execute_shell command to run the code. We can try the latter solution again, but this time we need to make sure that the LISP code does not use any functions that are already defined in the COMMON-LISP package, as this can cause a package lock error.
thoughts.plan:
- Save the LISP code to a .lisp file
- Use the execute_shell command to run the code
- Make sure that the LISP code does not use any functions that are already defined in the COMMON-LISP package
thoughts.speak: I suggest saving the LISP code to a .lisp file and using the execute_shell command to run the code. Make sure that the LISP code does not use any functions that are already defined in the COMMON-LISP package.
